verses.verse: Right away in the morning the chief priests held counsel with the elders, scribes, and the whole council and bound Jesus with chains, lead him away, and delivered him to Pilate.
Pilate asked him, "Are you the king of the Jews?" He replied saying to him, "As you say."
The chief priests accused him of many things, but he returned no answer.
Pilate asked him again saying, "Do you give an answer? Look, how many things they witness against you."
But still Jesus didn't answer, so that Pilate was amazed.
Now at that feast he released to them one prisoner, whomever they wanted.
There was one named Barabbas, bound with chains along with those who had committed murder in the insurrection.
The crowd started shouting desiring for him to do as he had previously done for them.
Pilate answered them saying, "Do you want me to release the King of the Jews to you?"
For he knew that the chief priests had delivered him because of envy.
But the chief priests stirred up the people, so that he should release Barabbas to them.
Pilate answered and said again to them, "What do you want me to do with him whom you call "The King of the Jews?"
Again they shouted out, "Crucify him!"
Then Pilate said to them, "Why, what evil has he done?" And they shouted even louder, "Crucify him!"
And Pilate wanting to please the people released Barabbas to them and delivered Jesus, after he had whipped him, to be crucified.
The soldiers led him away into the hall named Praetorium, and they called together the whole band of soldiers.
They dressed him with a purple robe, and they braided a crown of thorns and placed it on his head.
Then they started to salute him, "Hail, King of the Jews!"
They whacked him on the head with a reed, spit on him, and bowing their knees "worshipped" him.
After they had mocked him, they took off the purple robe from him and put his own clothes on him, then they led him out to crucify him.
Then they forced one, Simon, a Cyrenian-the father of Alexander and Rufus-who passed by, coming out of the country, to bear his cross.
They brought him to the place Golgotha, which is by interpretation, "The Place of a Skull."
They gave him a drink of wine mixed with myrrh, but he didn't take any.
After they had nailed him on the cross, they separated his clothes and cast lots on them to decide what every man should take.
It was about the third hour, when they crucified him.
The superscription of his accusation was written: "The King of the Jews."
They also crucified with him two thieves, one on his right hand and the other on his left.
Then the Scripture was fulfilled which said: "And he was numbered with the lawless."
And those who passed by insulted him, shaking their heads, and saying, "O, you who would destroy the temple and build it in three days;
"Save yourself, and come down from the cross."
In the same way the chief priests also mocking said among themselves along with the scribes, "He saved others, but he cannot save himself.
"Let Messiah, the King of the Jews, come down off the cross, so we can see and believe." And those who were crucified with him insulted him.
When the sixth hour had come, there was darkness over the whole land until the ninth hour.
At the ninth hour Jesus shouted with a loud voice saying, "Eloi, Eloi, lama sabachthani." Which is interpreted, "My God, my God, why have you forsaken me?"
Some of those who stood there, on hearing this, said, "Look, he calls for Elijah."
And someone ran and filled a sponge full of vinegar, stuck it on a reed, and gave him a drink saying, "Let him alone, let's see whether Elijah will come to take him down."
Then Jesus shouted with a loud voice and gave up his spirit.
Then the veil of the temple was torn in two from the top to the bottom.
When the centurion, who stood opposite him, saw that he shouted out this way and gave up his spirit said, "Truly, this man was the Son of God."
There were also women watching from afar, among them was Mary Magdalene, Mary, the mother of James the less and Joses, and Salome.
Who, when he was in Galilee, also followed him and ministered to him. Many other women who came up with him to Jerusalem [were also there].
Now when evening came, because it was the Preparation, that is, the day before the Sabbath,
Joseph of Arimathaea, an honorable counselor, who also waited for the kingdom of God, came and boldly went in to Pilate and begged for the body of Jesus.
Pilate was surprised if he would already be dead, so calling the centurion, he asked him whether he had been dead for awhile.
When he knew from the centurion, he gave the body to Joseph.
He bought fine linen and took him down. He wrapped him in the linen and laid him in a tomb, which was hewn out of a rock, and then he rolled a stone over the door of the tomb.
Mary Magdalene and Mary the mother of Joses saw where he was laid.
